descMeta.title: Rockefeller Hall, Brown University, Providence, Rhode Island, circa 1915-1930
Rockefeller Hall, Brown University, Providence, R.I.
descMeta.description: Rockefeller Hall at Brown University, Providence, Rhode Island, circa 1915-1930. Postmark date: September 10; Postcard number: 10708; Message included. Message reads: "Dear Friend Seizzie [?], I received your postal, or rather the one directed to mother. I wrote last to you , I forget so about my letters that now as soon as I receive a letter I put it in one particular apartment and as I answer it, I put it in another one so I can keep the run of them better now. Mother fails so gradually every day you hardly notice it. She sits up every day. Only think her birthday is almost here. 100 years old. I think she will live to see it. Hope to receive a letter from you soon. By by with love. H.S.F."
descMeta.rights: Collection may be protected under Title 17 of the U.S. Copyright Law. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the University of Maryland Libraries at http://www.lib.umd.edu/NTL/queries.html.

descMeta.title: The Rose Marie Grentzer Papers
descMeta.description: Rose Marie Grentzer (1914-1985) was a music educator who helped raise awareness about and fostered scholarship on audio-visual aids, international music education, and American music. After leading and enhancing music education programs at Juilliard, the University of Michigan, and Oberlin, she developed the graduate program in music education at the University of Maryland. Professor Grentzer taught and gave speeches throughout the world; was active in the Music Educators National Conference (MENC) (later the National Association for Music Education (NAfME)), Sigma Alpha Iota International Music Fraternity, and numerous other organizations; and cultivated the University of Maryland Madrigal Singers into an international touring choral group. This collection contains papers from her professional activities, organizational affiliations, and personal relationships, as well as photographs, correspondence, recordings, sheet music, subject files, embossers, posters, a scrapbook, certificates, and yearbooks.

descMeta.title: Pyon Su's diploma, June 24, 1891
descMeta.description: Pyon Su's diploma, conferred on June 24, 1891. Pyon Su (also known as Su Penn or Penn Su) was the first Korean student to graduate from any American college or university. "The Maryland Agricultural College INCORPORATED BY THE STATE OF MARYLAND. THE TRUSTEES To all and Singular Whom it may Concern, GREETING: We do by these Presents Testify, that Su Penn has completed the course of Study prescribed by this COLLEGE, for the attainment of the Degree of BACHELOR OF SCIENCE, and that we have conferred, and do hereby confer on him that DEGREE, together with all the rights and privileges appertaining thereto. In Testimony Whereof, witness the signatures of the President of the Board of Trustees and the Faculty of the College, with the Seal of the Corporation, this Twenty-fourth day of June, in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and ninety-one."

descMeta.title: Paul Traver Papers
descMeta.description: This collection includes administrative and personal records of Paul Traver (March 27, 1931 - March 27, 2011). Traver served on the faculty of the University of Maryland, Department of Music from 1957 to 1999. During his tenure, he founded the University of Maryland Chorus in 1967, co-founded the Maryland Handel Festival with Howard Serwer in 1981, and co-founded the American Handel Society with Serwer and J. Merrill Knapp in 1986. The bulk of the records pertain to Travers position as a faculty member of the University of Maryland. This collection includes correspondence, logistical and financial records, photographs, and audiovisual materials pertaining to the Maryland Handel Festival, University of Maryland Chorus, University of Maryland Administration, other choral ensembles at the University of Maryland, other ensembles that Traver conducted, and Travers personal life.
descMeta.subject: Performing Arts, Music
University of Maryland
Education

descMeta.title: Marcia Herndon Papers
descMeta.description: Marcia Alice Herndon (1941-1997) was a musicologist, educator, and researcher. Throughout her career she served as a Professor of Musicology and Ethnomusicology at the University of California at Berkeley and the University of Maryland. In addition to her professorship, she also authored and co-authored many notable publications, including Music as Culture (1979) with Norma McLeod. As a researcher, she specialized in ethnomusicology, Eastern Band Cherokee music and the traditions of people indigenous to North America, and the relationship between gender and musical performance. The Marcia Herndon Papers consists of both professional and personal papers and covers the period from 1830 to 1995; the bulk of materials date from 1968 to 1994. Documents include professional and personal writings, books and publications, correspondence, translations and field notes, audio/visual materials, and memorabilia.

descMeta.title: Maryland state of mind, [Spring 1996]
Life's a beach
Pests by design
Ready, willing, and A.B.L.E
We have liftoff
Twist of lime
Street law
descMeta.description: Life's a beach is a profile of "Dr. Beach", Dr. Leatherman, of the Laboratory for Coastal Research at the University of Maryland at College Park and his study of beaches rating quality of sand, surf, and atmosphere. Pests by design illustrates the University of Maryland Biotechnology Institute's involvement in genetic engineering of insects to deal with numerous agricultural issues. Ready, willing, and A.B.L.E. discusses Salisbury State University's internship program Applied Business Learning Experience (ABLE) which supplements classroom theory with field assignments and hands on consulting projects. We have liftoff! discusses Bowie State University's collaboration with NASA to establish a program dedicated to improvement in science and technology higher education. A twist of lime examines the revival of Western Maryland rivers through efforts of The Center for Environmental and Estuarine Studies which uses limestone to sweeten once dead, overly acidic waters which resulted from acid mine drainage. Street law discuesses the revitalization of Baltimore's Park Heights neighborhood through collaboration between University of Maryland School of Law and residents as they use Maryland laws to force owners of vacant, rundown properties to make them habitable or relinquish them to homesteaders.
Host, Scott Simon. Narrators, Betsy Ames, Mike Pengra.

descMeta.title: Maryland state of mind [winter 2000]
There's a bug in it
Sun bird
Shades of genius
Growth industry
Not just pills & powders
Widening their web
Turning a school around
descMeta.description: In There's a bug in it, students at University of Maryland, College Park, Department of Entomology are using advanced technology and a method called systematics biology to classify various types of insects. In Sun bird, Bowie State University monitors the sun with satellites and prepares for the possibility of its violent eruptions that have been predicted this year. Shades of genius profiles the Meyerhoff Program of Universtiy of Maryland, Baltimore County that aims to recruit minority students into scinece and engineering careers. Growth industry shows how University of Maryland Eastern Shore professors and students are designing and building environmentally advanced greenhouses to improve the agricultural industry of the Eastern Shore. In Not just pills & powders, University of Maryland at Baltimore School of Pharmacy looks at how the training of pharmicists has changed over the years. Widening the web profiles University of Maryland University College Institute for Distance Education where students can now take all of their classes online and receive a degree without ever entering a classroom. Turning a school around shows how Coppin State College professors and students are training the teachers at Rosemont Elementary School in a poverty-stricken area of Baltimore to be better educators in hopes of improving poor student performance.
Host, Scott Simon.
Dolby surround.

descMeta.title: Fair play
Achieving gender equity in the digital age
descMeta.description: Narrator, Regina Taylor. Producer, director, writer, Sue Ellen McCann ; series creator, executive producer, David Bolt ; associate producer, Rachel Raney ; editor, Wendy Wank.

Exposes counterproductive classroom behaviors and presents measures being taken to correct the misperception that computing is a males-only domain. Professionals in education scrutinize issues including equal computer access in the classroom, attitude barriers both in class and out, and efforts to develop software and Web sites that enfranchise female users rather than reinforce gender stereotypes.

descMeta.title: From Washington : report on integration
Report on integration
Integration : complying with Brown in 1957
Complying with Brown in 1957
descMeta.description: [produced by CBS News]. Panelists: Weldon James, Joseph Parham, Don Shoemaker, W.D. Workman, Jr.; moderator, Griffing Bancroft.

In 1957, the eyes of America were on Little Rock, where the compulsory desegregation of Central High School was front-page news. But what about the broader picture? How successful had integration efforts in the South been in the three years following the Brown decision? This program, filmed in that year, brings together a panel of newsmen from the Southern Education Reporting Service to assess-against the backdrop of anti-integration violence-the overall progress being made in complying with the U.S. Supreme Court's ruling.

descMeta.description: In Virus hunter Robert C. Gallo discusses his research on the AIDS virus and the relationship between research and clinical practice. Digital diplomats discusses the International Communication and Negotion Simulation which is comprised of students at more than 40 colleges and universities in over 20 countries. An ICONS simulation places students in the role of negotiators in teams representing various countries. Mapping with a mouse discusses how Towson State University is using geographic information systems to create maps and assist Maryland counties in planning development. Higher learning discusses Bowie State University's Satellite Operations and Control Center where students get hands-on experience tracking satellites. Rx from an RV examines the well-mobile that travels from the University of Maryland at Baltimore's School of Nursing to communities to provide free health services. Foreign exchange illustrates a program where Russian politicians visit the Maryland General Assembly to observe the legislative process.

descMeta.title: Maryland state of mind, [Winter 1998]
This old hall
Lights, camera, traction
All things conserved
Diagnosis of the deep
Bright star shines on
Bogeys, birdies and frogs
Memories of the shore
descMeta.description: In This old hall, Maryland students travel to England to visit and help restore the birthplace of Lord Baltimore, founder of the colony of Maryland. Lights, camera, traction! takes a look at the University's Shock Trauma telemedicine techniques to aid stroke victims. All things conserved visits the National Public Broadcasting Archives at the University of Maryland Libraries and gives insight as to how they are preserving old television and radio broadcasts. In Diagnosis of the deep, scientists explore why the Chesapeake Bay consistently produces such a large number of fish. A bright star shines on introduces African American astronaut Ronald McNair, a member of the Challanger team of 1986, and how his memory lives on through a scholarship program established at Coppin State College in his name. Bogeys, birdies and frogs profiles how a Frostburg State University professor is helping golfers and frogs live in harmony on the fairway and discusses other environmental restoration and wildlife management techniques for golf courses. Memories of the shore shows how old historical records from settlers of Maryland are being preserved and shared at a museum in Salisbury.
Host: Scott Simon. Narrators: Betsy Ames, Mike Pengra, Carol Mason.

Wisdom through a wire
Microbe wars
Meeting the challenge
It's about time
Hypermedium is the message

Better mousetrap
descMeta.description: Wisdom through a wire illustrates the Tycho computer system at University of Maryland University College and its use in distance education. Microbe wars discusses research and development of vaccines at the University of Maryland at Baltimore's School of Medicine. Meeting the challenge discusses the Choices program in Baltimore that recruits recent college graduates to counsel and help troubled young people. It's about time visits John Robinson to discuss his research into how people manage their time now, and how they did in the past. The hypermedium is the message illustrates how the University of Baltimore's Institute for Language, Technology, and Publications Design helps students and faculty design hypermedia applications. Learning to think, thinking to learn examines a program started by Coppin State College, where students (grades 4-9) come to school on Saturday to learn how to become better thinkers. A better mousetrap discusses the MIPS, Maryland Industrial Partnerships, program in which business and researchers work together on developing new products, such as airplane wings, and more fuel efficient ignition systems.
Host, Scott Simon. Narrators, Betsy Ames, Mike Pengra.

descMeta.title: Maryland state of mind, [Fall 1996]
Military intelligence
Laughing all the way to the lab
Growing smarter
Dental records
Sound advice
Ahead of the class
It's the economy, professor
descMeta.description: Military intelligence illustrates how professors from University of Maryland University College travel to over 125 U.S. military bases around the world to teach college course for enlisted people. Laughing all the way to the lab visits Prof. Robert R. Provine as he conducts research on why people laugh. Growing smarter discusses urban sprawl around Washington D.C. and Baltimore. Dental records visits the Dr. Samuel D. Harris National Museum of Dentistry at the University of Maryland at Baltimore. Sound advice illustrates how Towson State University students are trained to treat speech and hearing disorders. Ahead of the class examines the Lockheed Martin graduate fellows program, in which school teachers spend their summers as paid researchers. It's the economy, professor discusses a study by the Robert G. Merrick School of Business at the University of Baltimore that found the perception that Maryland was unfriendly toward business was caused by the complicated procedure of filing environmental permits. The process was streamlined and businesses have increased their investment in the state.
Host, Scott Simon.

descMeta.title: Maryland state of mind, [Fall 1997]
Robot ruckus
World harmony
Lessons from the dead
Command performance
Crab lab
Artist's touch
Lasting impression
descMeta.description: Robot ruckus examines University of Maryland College Park engineering and computer science students who win an international robotics competition in Tokyo, Japan with their robot jouster Lancelot. World harmony illustrates the World Cello Congress II which took place in St. Petersburg, Russia and featured violoncellists from 20 countries and was organized by Towson State University. Lessons from the dead illustrates the history of Maryland's first medical school at University of Maryland highlighting the early use of body snatchers to collect freshly buried corpses for anatomy classes. Command performance examines the University of Maryland Baltimore County drama department's performance of the play, Diary of a Scoundrel, at the John F. Kennedy Center. Maryland blue crab waterman turns to aquaculture experts at the University of Maryland Eastern Shore in efforts to learn more about the physiology and biology of crabs to keep them alive until they shed into soft crabs in Crab lab. An artist's touch illustrates art exhibits featuring the Maryland Artists Collection are displayed at the University of Maryland Universtiy College Conference Center; highlights include works by Maryland artists Herman Maril, Selma Oppenheimer and Perna Krick, and African-American painter Preston Sampson. Lasting impression discusses the University of Maryland's increasing dependence on individual and corporate financial assistance in the forms of grants, endowments, scholarships and gifts due to declines in state and federal funding.
Host, Scott Simon. Narrators, Betsy Ames, Mike Pengra.

descMeta.title: Maryland state of mind, [Spring 1998]
Portable plague
Helping out at home
Blight in the Bay
Be our guest
Calming effect
Estrogen: assessing its power
Quality control
descMeta.description: The portable plague describes the Black Plague and examines the use of biological weapons in modern warfare as studied by the University of Maryland Biotechnology Institute. Helping out at home shows how Peace Corps volunteers from the University of Maryland, Baltimore County use their experiences in third world countries to help solve local problems such as drug and alcohol addiction. A blight in the Bay examines the problem of Piscicides that are polluting the bay and poisoning fish. Be our guest profiles the hotel restaurant management program at University of Maryland Eastern Shore and how it trains students the science of entertaining tourists. A calming effect looks at the role of conflict in our lives and nonviolent solutions such as mediation. Estrogen: assessing its power focuses on the role of the female hormone in woman's health and sexuality as studied by the University of Maryland School of Medicine. Quality control features the business management program at the University of Maryland, College Park and stresses the importance of teamwork and good problem solving skills.
Host: Scott Simon.

descMeta.title: Maryland state of mind [Fall 1998]
Fabric of their lives
Birdmen of Catonsville
Music man
Millennium bug
I hear a symphony
Meeting of the minds
Work study
descMeta.description: In The fabric of their lives, the University of Maryland Biotechnology Institute becomes involved in research to control cholera in Bangladesh. In The birdmen of Catonsville, scientists at University of Maryland, Baltimore County use high-end technology in research efforts to minimize avian accidents between birds and aircraft. In The music man, Bill Cummings, composer and choir director at Coppin State College, creates an original soundtrack for a classic silent film. In The millennium bug, University System of Maryland trains students as programmers to interface with companies to deal with the year 2000 computer date conversion crisis, the "Y2K problem." In I hear a symphony, University of Maryland, College Park hosts the National Orchestra Institute, an intense annual summer program for selected music students culminating in three public concerts. In A meeting of the minds, Salisbury State University hosts the National Conference on Undergraduate Research (NCUR) where over 2,000 undergraduates and advisors from the United States and foreign countries meet to explore the importance of the research experience. Work study focuses on how the University of Maryland at Baltimore is involved in a study to assess effects of the 1996 Federal Welfare Reform Act on Maryland welfare recipients.
Host, Scott Simon. Narrators, Betsy Ames, Mike Pengra.

descMeta.title: Maryland state of mind, [Winter 1999]
descMeta.description: Hungry for Hollywood illustrates how Towson University's Mass Communication program teaches techniques of filmmaking and highlights a recent graduate who landed a job working in Hollywood. Name, rank and G.P.A. examines how the University of Maryland University College's Asia Division provides higher education classes to American military personnel stationed in Korea. Softer software visits University of Maryland College Park researchers at the Human-Computer Interaction Lab who are working to develop ways of making computers easier to use, including working with young children. The sky's the limit examines the University of Maryland Eastern Shore's new major in aviation which covers all elements of the aviation industry and provides students with a four year aviation science degree. Seeing the forest and the trees visits Frostburg State University scientists, ecologists and ornithologists who are learning about the forces which shape old growth forests in efforts to save them from dangers such as the logging industry and foreign introduced insects. Rockfish resurgence visits University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science scientists who are looking for causes of past population declines of striped bass, or rockfish, in efforts to prevent declines in the future. Something for the pain illustrates how the University of Maryland at Baltimore is involved in the Regional Center for Persistent and Chronic Pain which is headquarted at the University of Maryland at Baltimore, School of Dentistry and teams University of Maryland with Johns Hopkins University in research into chronic pain management.
Host, Scott Simon. Narrators, Betsy Ames, Mike Pengra.

Bard is back
Und all that jazz
ReOrienting medicine
Perfect instrument
Once upon a time
Street legal
Line in the sand
descMeta.description: In The bard is back, Leeds Barrol of the University of Maryland, Baltimore County and Hardy Cook of Bowie State University discuss their research on William Shakespeare. Und all that jazz features a Towson University trio giving a musical performance at Oldenburg University, Germany celebrating George Gershwin. In ReOrienting medicine, University of Maryland School of Medicine creates the nation's first academic center for study of complementary medicine. The perfect instrument features the Marian Anderson International Vocal Competition, sponsored by the University of Maryland, College Park and held at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. Once upon a time profiles Frostburg State University's summer Author Institute featuring children's book authors, and illustrator Kevin O'Malley. In Street legal, University of Baltimore law students work with citizens of Baltimore through their Community Development Clinic. A line in the sand shows how University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science researchers study rising sea levels of the Chesapeake Bay.
Host, Scott Simon. Narrators, Betsy Ames, Mike Pengra.

descMeta.title: Maryland state of mind, [spring 2000]
Glass act
Food for thought
Memories to share
Splendor in the grass
Making a name for themselves
Smile a mile wide
descMeta.description: In Man the "terpedo", engineering students at the University of Maryland, College Park design and build a human-powered submarine. A glass act discusses the glass blowing sculpture program at Salisbury State University. Food for thought discusses how scientists at the University of Maryland Biotechnology Institute are studying the genetic modification of plant and animal foods. Memories to share discusses "Passager", a literary journal produced by the University of Baltimore. Splendor in the grass discusses a program coordinated by the University of Maryland Center for Environmental Science which enables school children and teachers to conduct scientific experiments in the Chesapeake Bay. Making a name for themselves discusses a group of eighty freshman at Frostburg State University who are conducting volunteer service in their community by participating in he Americorps program. A smile a mile wide discusses a program at the University of Maryland Dental School which provides dental care for economically challenged children.
Host, Scott Simon. Narrators, Betsy Ames, Mike Pengra.
Dolby surround.

descMeta.title: Maryland state of mind, [fall 2000]
Science on the half shell
Unearthing a golden past
Path of pathogens
Modern forces, ancient empires
Worries about wheat
Notes of emotion
descMeta.description: In the vicinity of Vesuvius discusses how a team of architects and students from the University of Maryland, College Park is working with Italian authorities to turn a site at Pompeii into an archaeological park. Science on the half shell discusses how scientists from the University of Maryland Biotechnology Institute are developing new tests to detect diseases in oysters. Unearthing a golden past discusses how members of the University of Maryland, Baltimore County's Ancient Studies department are studying some of Maryland's archaeological sites. The path of pathogens discusses how researchers at the University of Maryland, Eastern Shore are studying how bacteria can enter the food chain in the poultry industry. Modern forces, ancient empires discusses how the University of Maryland, University College is providing college courses for naval forces stationed in Italy. Worries about wheat discusses how researchers at the University of Maryland School of Medicine are studying celiac disease. Notes of emotion discusses the World Cello Congress III at Towson University.
Host, Scott Simon. Narrators, Betsy Ames, John Badila.
Dolby surround.

descMeta.title: To William P. Preston from Anonymous, Account of Father James Dolan, 1870
descMeta.description: Account of the life and work of Father James Dolan of Baltimore sent to William P. Preston by an anonymous individual, dated November 14, 1870. Includes pages numbered 1 to 6 and 18 to 25. The account begins in 1847 with the arrival of Irish emigrants to Baltimore and their "destitute condition" which aroused Father Dolan and members of The Hibernian Society to provide assistance to them and continues with entries from Father Dolan's diary describing work among the Baltimore poor. Preston was a member of The Hibernian Society, a charitable organization for Irish emigrants in the state of Maryland.

descMeta.title: Maryland state of mind, [Winter 1996]
Voyage to an ancient harbor
All the world's a stage
Marching home
Ounce of prevention
People's channel
Clean genes
Tuning in to language
descMeta.description: In Voyage to an ancient harbor, University of Maryland College Park archaeologists uncover the ancient Roman port of Caesarea Maritima in what is now Israel. In All the world's a stage, Towson State University's theater program hosts a Kabuki master. Marching home features a Frostburg State University conference on the cultural legacy of World War II. An ounce of prevention shows how University of Maryland at Baltimore's community health worker program is improving the lives of chronically ill patients, reducing Medicaid cost, and training neighbors to help neighbors. In The people's channel, Coppin State College profiles Baltimore Cable Access Corporation (BCAC) and its public access cable television station. Clean genes shows how University of Maryland Biotechnology Institute uses genetic engineering of an enzyme to make laundry detergents more effective and environmentally friendly. Tuning in to language shows how University of Maryland, Baltimore County is packaging foreign language television broadcasts as an innovative teaching tool.
Host, Scott Simon.

descMeta.title: Maryland state of mind, [Spring 1999]
Bird in the bush
Gideon's trumpet
Going to bat one more time
Chess set
Hitting a high note
Virtue is its own reward
In the pink
descMeta.description: In Bird in the bush, students from University of Maryland, College Park study the mating rituals of the Bower bird of Australia. Gideon's trumpet features University of Maryland at Baltimore School of Law conference on Gideon v. Wainwright, the landmark court case which brought about the inception of the right to a public attorney. Going to bat one more time highlights the career of Baltimore Orioles outfielder Paul Blair and shows him in his new job as the head coach of the Coppin State College baseball team. The chess set focuses on University of Maryland, Baltimore County chess champions. Hitting a high note features Bowie State University's music department and how they use the new technology in their music. Virtue is its own reward focuses on University of Maryland Biotechnology Institute's international virtual research project on water pollution in the Chesapeake Bay. In the pink shows how students from Salisbury State University are studying plant bacterium.
Host, Scott Simon.

descMeta.title: To Madge Preston from William P. Preston, circa 1856-1858
descMeta.description: Thirty-one letters from William P. Preston to Madge Preston. Thirteen letters from 1856: April 3, April 20, April 23, April 23, May 9, May 10, May 12, May 15, May 18, May 27, July 17, July 24, July 24; eleven letters from 1857: January 4, January 7, January 9, January 12, January 18, January 19, January 22, June 25, July 13, July 28, October 12; seven letters from 1858: April 26, [?], August 13, September 16, September 21, September 24, September 25.
